title: How to Get Rid of Lice in Your Home

steps.headline: Vacuum the floor and furniture.
steps.description: Lice can’t survive for more than 1-2 days once they’ve been separated from human hair, and even then the chances of getting lice from furniture, clothing, or other items are slim. Still, it’s better to be safe than sorry. Focus on cleaning floor coverings such as rugs and mats, all cloth furniture, and large pillows. Pay special attention to those areas and items that have been in contact with someone who’s recently had lice.

steps.headline: Make sure your mattress is lice-free.
steps.description: You spend hours a day sleeping in your bed, which means lice on your head would spend a lot of time there, too. Remove linens and vacuum the bare mattress thoroughly. Be sure to focus on the areas where the treated person lays his or her head, and don’t forget to vacuum in the corners and along the edges of the mattress. Get under any mattress pads or protectors. All bedding and mattress pads should be washed in a washing machine using hot water.

steps.headline: Clean out your car, including all carseats and headrests.
steps.description: You probably spend a fair amount of time in your car, and sometimes hair comes in direct contact with the car’s interior. Vacuum carseats and headrests thoroughly. As a further precaution, you can put pillowcases or plastic bags over the headrests to prevent lice from spreading to your hair or your passengers’ hair. If you have a child who sits in a carseat or booster seat, take off the seat cover and put it in the dryer on high heat for 40 minutes, or seal in a plastic bag for 5 days. If your car has a leather interior, you can use wipes or a damp cloth to wipe down the seats and headrests.

steps.headline: Collect items to wash.
steps.description: Anything that’s come in contact with a person who’s had lice is worth cleaning. Gather any clothing, linens, pillows, hats, gloves, and coats that could have lice or nits on them, and put them in plastic bags.

steps.headline: Wash infested items in hot water.
steps.description: Lice can’t survive for long once separated from a person’s head, but just in case you can machine-wash these items in hot, soapy water. Make sure the water is at least 130 degrees F (54.4 C) to kill off the lice.

steps.headline: Dry on high heat.
steps.description: The heat produced from your dryer is a very effective way to kill any lice still remaining on your belongings. For any items that can’t handle the heat, you can always seal them in bags for a few days, or put them in your freezer for 12 hours.

steps.headline: Soak combs and brushes in hot water.
steps.description: Any products that come in contact with hair, like combs, brushes, or hair accessories, should be cleaned to make sure no lice or nits are hiding on them. Soak them in hot, soapy water that’s 130 degrees F (54.4 C) for 5-10 minutes. Bag and seal any items that can’t be washed. For items that can’t be easily or safely washed--certain articles of clothing, toys, accessories--you can seal them in plastic bags for two weeks. Any lice on these items won’t be able to survive without a source of food, and their eggs won’t be able to hatch. Dry-cleaning is also a safe option for cleaning clothes that can’t go in a washing machine.

steps.headline: Avoid sharing items that touch your head or someone else’s.
steps.description: There’s nothing worse than thinking your lice-free, only to find they’ve returned. Although it’s pretty unlikely, items such as hats, scarves, headphones, and hair accessories can carry lice from one host to another.

steps.headline: Refrain from head-to-head contact.
steps.description: Coming in direct contact with another person’s head, whether through sports or another activity, is the easiest way to get lice. Try to minimize the times you touch another person’s hair to prevent the spread.

steps.headline: Avoid sitting on potentially lice-infested furniture.
steps.description: Don't sit on couches or chairs where a person with lice has been until thoroughly cleaned. This includes beds, couches, armchairs, as well as linens and pillows. Keeping yourself away from the furniture and belongings of someone who has lice or has recently had lice is a good precaution to make sure you and the rest of your family stay lice-free.

steps.headline: Be on the lookout and check for lice regularly.
steps.description: Getting lice is never totally preventable, unfortunately. The best you can do is pay attention to the signs and symptoms, making sure to check from time to time. Doing the occasional lice check will not only put your mind at ease, but it’ll also help you control any lice you do find before it becomes a bigger problem.
